originalText.text:
The University Heights Bridge is a steel-truss revolving swing bridge across the Harlem River. It connects West 207th Street in the Inwood neighborhood of Manhattan with West Fordham Road in the Bronx's University Heights neighborhood. The bridge is operated and maintained by the New York City Department of Transportation.
The bridge carries two lanes of traffic in each direction and a sidewalk on its southern side. The bridge has three masonry piers supporting the steel approach spans. The sidewalk features four shelters with cast-iron supports, while the bridge deck has decorative iron railings and two stone pavilions.
The bridge structure was originally installed further to the north, carrying Broadway across the Harlem River Ship Canal. It opened in 1895 as the Harlem Ship Canal Bridge and was relocated southward to University Heights in 1908. Over the following decades, the University Heights Bridge carried streetcar and bus service. By the late 20th century, it was in disrepair. The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission designated the University Heights Bridge as a city landmark in 1984, and it was completely rebuilt between 1989 and 1992.

originalText.text: It is a very nicely constructed bridge so it's a shame that it's been blighted with graffiti. Perhaps they DOT ought to consider adding a protected bicycle/micromobility lane due to the cyclists and mopeds refusing to dismount and share the small cement walkway with pedestrians. As a pedestrian you are expected to get out of their way or get hit and it's quite annoying and could potentially be hazardous.

originalText.text: When I do not feel like taking the bus home I walk from 207 street all the way home. But the only problem that I have is that the some people ride there motorcycle or scooters even people with there bike that has the lithium battery go really fast on the bridge when they should be in the street. That is not good especially when people are walking.

originalText.text:
Really nice bridge.
Picture taken from a boat ride with the Circle Line around Manhattan.

originalText.text: Each of the more than two dozen bridges connecting Manhattan to another part of the boroughs has its own distinct character. I most remember approaching the Fordham Road bridge/University Heights Bridge a few years after my first circumnavigation of Manhattan and, admittedly, feeling pretty tired. I then was happy when I saw the Sharp boathouse because I recalled it (inaccurately) as being closer to Inwood Park, where I was going to take out, than it is in reality was.
